citation: Parmakelis, A. 2023. Mastus unius. The IUCN Red List of Threatened Species 2023: e.T157079A742738. https://dx.doi.org/10.2305/IUCN.UK.2023-1.RLTS.T157079A742738.en. Accessed on 03 December 2024.

ssc_groups.name: IUCN SSC Mollusc Specialist Group
ssc_groups.description:
Chair and Mollusc RLA Coordinator: Mary Seddon (email: mary.molluscsg@gmail.com)
Cephalapod RLA Coordinator: Louise Allcock (email: louise.allcock@nuigalway.ie)
Cone Snail RLA Coordinator: Under discussion
European Land Snails RLA Coordinator: Eike Neubert (email: eike.neubert@nmbe.ch)
Australian Land and Freshwater Molluscs: Frank Kohler (email: Frank.Koehler@austmus.gov.au)
Freshwater Bivalves: Manuel Lopes-Lima (email: lopeslima.ciimar@gmail.com)

documentation.range: The taxonomy of this species is under debate. As accepted currently, it may have a restricted distribution somewhere in the Aegean Sea. However, it may be a synonym of the wider spread Mastus pusio (Heller 1976, Mylonas 1982). Therefore, it is difficult to confirm the actual distribution of this species.
documentation.population: There are no population data available for this species. Taxonomic research is needed to confirm whether it is a valid species or part of a more widespread species.
documentation.habitats: Species within the genus Mastus generally are soil-dwelling species, usually found in xeric shrublands (maquis and phrygana) (Parmakelis 2003).
documentation.threats: Before threats can be identified for this species, its taxonomy and distribution needs to be confirmed.
documentation.measures: Mastus unius was listed as Least Concern in the 2009 Greek national Red List (Legakis and Maragkou 2009). Priority research for this species is on clarifying the taxonomy, distribution and threats.
documentation.rationale: This mollusc species is considered endemic to Greece. However, there is considerable confusion over its taxonomy, which makes it difficult to determine its distribution and current or potential threats. Therefore, currently it is not possible to assess it beyond Data Deficient.
documentation.taxonomic_notes: The taxonomy of this species is currently under debate. It may be a synonym of Mastus pusio (Heller 1976, Mylonas 1982), however it is still listed as a valid species in MolluscaBase (2023).
